posts.name: Isaac Mendoza
posts.cooked: Our team has been using 6-gauge power wire for some time now and is considering a switch to 4-gauge due to its lower resistance and because many top-tier bots in our district utilize 4-gauge or even smaller wiring. We would appreciate it if someone could list the advantages and disadvantages of both types of wires.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
We switched from 6 AWG to 4 AWG batteries this year because we noticed that the 6 AWG wires became quite warm during battery swaps. Additionally, we reduced the cable lengths—our battery cables are now approximately four inches long, with one of the cables connecting to the Power Distribution Panel being just one inch long. While we haven’t systematically measured the electrical impact of these changes, we haven’t experienced the same “warm wires” issue since making the switch. A downside is that installing the 4 AWG wires requires more effort to fit them into the Anderson terminals, but this is manageable.

We have observed that longer runs of 12 AWG wiring can significantly affect performance. Specifically, our algae shooting motor, located at the end of about 8 feet of wire, occasionally draws the maximum current, causing the controller to report a drop of around one volt compared to the RIO reading. This results in about 60 watts of heat being dissipated in the wires.

posts.name: Isaac Mendoza
posts.cooked: Do you guys put 4-gauge wire into SB50’s or SB120’s? I’m also concerned about the price of changing to 4-gauge. How was the transition for you?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: We use SB50 wiring, primarily because we already have a large quantity on hand. As I mentioned earlier, using a smaller wire gauge in a terminal designed for 6-gauge isn’t ideal. If we were starting from scratch, SB120 would be the appropriate choice. The cost of the wire itself is not a major concern since we don’t require extensive lengths.

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked: If you're considering upgrading your car audio system, choosing the right amplifier wiring is crucial. The sb50 and sb120 are likely referring to specific models of amplifiers, possibly from a brand like Pioneer. The sb50 typically supports up to 6-gauge wire, while the sb120 may accommodate larger gauges. Upgrading to 4-gauge wire can reduce resistance and voltage drop, enhancing performance. However, the cost of 4-gauge is generally higher than 10-gauge. Ensure compatibility by checking the amp's specifications. When installing, use the correct connectors and consider if the wire length or spacing requires adjustments. The material quality of the wire can impact durability, so it's worth researching wire types. Consulting user reviews or forums can provide insights and tips, ensuring a smooth upgrade process.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: We switched from 6 to 4 AWG a couple of years ago and started using SB120s. It provides a little relief from voltage drop, though it’s tricky to quantify exactly how much. If you regularly draw over 200A, it might be worth considering if you’re okay investing time and money. Additionally, you’ll need adapters, which are useful for connecting old robots, sharing batteries, or integrating with existing chargers. However, there’s an added challenge: unplugging the SB120 connectors can be tough on the fingers, especially if metal edges are nearby, leading to minor bumps.

link_counts.title: SB120 to SB50 Battery Adapter Cable - AndyMark, Inc

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked: With the increasingly popular Kraken and Vortex devices in use, anything you can do to reduce the current pathway resistance from the battery to the end device is well worth the effort. Evaluate all components, including PDP/Power Distribution Panel and PDH/Power Distribution Hub devices, letting the data guide your decisions.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: Remember you have to purchase some adapters too. These are for plugging into old robots, lending batteries to other teams, and plugging your batteries into existing battery chargers. You can also make adapters yourself, which is cheaper than buying them from Andymark, especially if you have SB50s just sitting around. Use very short 6ga wires between the SB50 and SB120 connectors (about 2"-3" works fine). That’s what we did and they work just fine for these purposes.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: You need to purchase some adapters, such as the SB120 to SB50 adapter, which are used for connecting to older robots, sharing batteries with other teams, and charging batteries in existing setups. While you can make your own adapters for a cheaper option, another consideration is the difficulty some team members might face when crimping 4AWG wires. Additionally, unplugging SB120 connectors can cause some wear on your knuckles, especially if there are metal corners nearby. Be sure to use flexible 4AWG cables to avoid discomfort. On the positive side, we no longer need to zip-tie SB120 units together to prevent them from coming apart during competitions.

In my experience, switching from 6AWG to 4AWG wire typically only resolves issues caused by poor crimps or connections in your existing setup. Other problems generally won't be fixed by this change, as the resistance difference is minimal for short runs. At my workplace, we don't measure wire resistance unless runs exceed 10 feet. If your battery leads are particularly long, shortening them could provide similar benefits.  

If you're experiencing issues, consider implementing current limits, ramping up acceleration, or using smaller motors. Ensure all wiring connections are secure. Switching isn't harmful, so if you're in an edge case where it might help, go ahead. Just make sure to use flexible, high-quality welding wire for better workability.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: With the increased use of devices like the Kraken and Vortex, efforts to reduce battery-to-device pathway resistance are worth it. However, if the same effort or resources could yield greater benefits elsewhere, such as investing in a vision system or improving your vehicle’s performance, then upgrading power cables might not be the most efficient use of your time and money.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: As far as I know, the battery voltage is typically around two-tenths of a volt at 250+ amps. It seemed beneficial last year, but in this year's game, we haven't pushed the batteries as hard. This may depend on the specific robot, though. Still, the gains are relatively minor compared to ensuring proper connections and regular maintenance of the batteries.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Matt Middleton
posts.cooked: We switched over during the offseason for several reasons, not solely related to performance and resistance. Prepare yourself for sticker shock when re-kitting with SB-120’s; these parts will cost a significant amount of money.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Not if that same effort or cost can achieve greater gains elsewhere. True. Switching to 4AWG wire, in addition to the time required (ideally done during the summer), will cost you approximately $17 per SB120, $2 per foot of wire, $2 per copper lug, and at least $35 for a good high-leverage crimping tool. If you're doing this, you might also consider using the grasshopper connectors at $8 per battery. For a dozen batteries, one charger, and one robot, the total cost could exceed $500, possibly calculated as follows: (16 x $17) + (30 x $2) + (24 x $2) + $35 + (12 x $8).

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: We minimized cable length. Just want to highlight this. Figuring out how to make your leads really, really short will generally give you as much gain as going to a smaller gauge. We do use 4AWG/SB120s for the marginal gain, but putting your battery, main breaker, and PDP all right next to each other will generally make a bigger difference.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked:
After removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements, here's the cleaned-up text:

Might be a hot take, but aside from lacking 4ga SB50 wire contacts, I have no concerns with using an SB50 with 4ga wire in our application. During my field inspections this year, I noticed that approximately 80% of teams using 4ga wire opt for the SB50, while 20% prefer the SB120. The main issue is that the largest available lug on the SB50 is 6ga.

For those wondering about the 50A rating of the SB50, refer to the product documentation from Anderson Power, which shows a UL 1977 rating of 120A. While the intended hot-plug rating is 50A, our application does not involve hot plugging, and even then, the unit would likely handle the load without issues. Using smaller wire is common in devices due to considerations for loading and heat dissipation. Our SB50s and 4ga wires operate in free-air environments, and our tests showed minimal heat buildup.

Regarding the lack of 4ga lugs, you can extend the existing 6ga lugs, though this requires careful trimming of strands. Alternatively, creative solutions like using 4ga-to-6ga adapters have been explored. For expansion, I’ve found that steel rods with appropriately shaped ends and lubrication work, albeit slowly. If anyone has a more efficient solution, feel free to share.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: 2363 produced a white paper on expanding the 6 AWG lugs.

link_counts.title: Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: I would prefer to use a more robust hydraulic crimp tool over the $35 crimp tool and invest in a higher-quality option like the TEMCo TH0006, which costs around $150. This model comes with half-size dies, which have been useful on occasion when dealing with non-standard lug nuts. I’ve heard that the Harbor Freight version of this tool is quite popular, priced at approximately $70, and often goes on sale at HF, especially if you’re buying multiple tools together.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: Nice, thanks!

posts.name: Cosimo Aho
posts.cooked:
Our team is transitioning from 6-gauge to 4-gauge copper wiring to help reduce voltage drop under load. Currently, our robot uses Kraken X60s and Falcon 500s, and we experience transient loads reaching approximately 175A. Although we haven't implemented the switch yet, the cost difference between the gauges is minimal, around $10 per wire, which is insignificant compared to expenses like the PDH, roboRIO, and other components. Be aware that new crimps and Anderson connectors compatible with 4-gauge wire will be required.

At 26 inches long, the electrical performance difference between the gauges is significant:
- **6-gauge**: Resistance = 0.8363 milliohms, Conductance = 1.1958 kS, Diameter = 4.11 mm
- **4-gauge**: Resistance = 0.5244 milliohms, Conductance = 1.907 kS, Diameter = 5.19 mm

In summary, the 4-gauge cable offers about 60% more conductivity compared to the 6-gauge option, with the added cost being less than double. This upgrade is expected to reduce voltage drop.
